title: Affinity and Packing of Benzene, Toluene, and
-Xylene Adsorption on a Graphitic Surface and in Pores
abstract: A grand canonical Monte Carlo simulation has been carried out at ambient temperature to investigate the adsorption of benzene, toluene, and

-xylene (BTX) on a graphite surface and in a graphitic slit and cylindrical pores. Particular emphasis has been paid to the effects of the confined space on the affinity and packing density. Simulation results for adsorption on a graphite surface were tested against the experimental data to validate the potential models used in the description of adsorption. Our extensive simulation has shown that on an open graphite surface, where there is no restriction in the packing,

-xylene has the highest affinity and adsorbed amount at a given reduced pressure and benzene has the lowest values, due to the additional interaction of the methyl groups with the surface. In a confined space, the order of the affinity remains the same, but the packing (hence the amount adsorbed per unit physical pore volume) is affected by the geometry of the space. It was found that benzene has the highest packing density, whether it is expressed in terms of moles or mass.
text: Benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) are hazardous organic compounds that are emitted from chemical and petrochemical industries. It has been reported that these aromatic hydrocarbons are neurotoxic and consequently cause diseases of the nervous system and sterility.

Stricter environmental regulations require that aromatics must be removed before the effluents can be safely discharged into the environment. Among the various technologies that are available, adsorption is the simplest means to achieve this goal with activated carbon (AC), silica gel, and zeolite being the possible candidates as adsorbents. Among them, AC is preferred because of its nonpolar surface and high surface area.
The physisorption of aromatics on a graphitic surface has been studied thoroughly both experimentally
the affinity for the adsorbent being the most important criterion for better design of an adsorption system. For example AC,
and advanced adsorbents with hexagonal pores

have all been the subject of investigation in the past decade. The affinity of the adsorbent for the adsorbate is characterized by the Henry constant and has been obtained experimentally for BTX in a number of carbonaceous systems at various temperatures.

These authors have shown that the order of affinity is B < T < X, due to the methyl groups attached to the benzene ring that augment the interaction with the surface. Although xylene is the strongest adsorbate on this basis, there are conflicting reports in the literature that the adsorption capacity for benzene is the highest (among BTX) in some activated carbons
but is the lowest in others.
This raises questions about the affinity and packing of BTX in a confined space. Although it has been reported that the surface functional group can have an effect on the packing,

we will concentrate our investigation on the effects of the confined space, in terms of its size and curvature and on the packing of BTX using a grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation. Simulation of benzene adsorption on a graphite surface has been studied previously.

On the other hand, there are no reports in the literature of simulation of toluene and xylene adsorption on a graphite surface, and we will therefore study their adsorption on a planar graphite surface first to establish suitable potential models and then investigate the effects of confinement on adsorption of toluene and xylene.
It has been found in our previous work

comprising six Lennard-Jones (LJ) sites and three charged sites can describe the experimental data for fluid benzene reasonably well, and we will employ these models here. The six LJ sites are at the centers of the carbon atoms of the aromatic ring with a C(aro)–C(aro) bond length of 1.40 Å. For toluene and xylene (only
-xylene is studied in this work), additional dispersive sites are located at the center of mass of the carbon atom of the methyl group and the C(aro)–CH

bond length is 1.54 Å. A positive partial charge (+2.42e) is placed at the center of the benzene ring, and two negative partial charges (−1.21e each) on both sides of the ring are placed at a distance of 0.785 Å normal to the ring to account for the quadrupole. Since toluene has a dipole, we investigate the effects of the dipole by using the OPLS-AA model.

We have presented computer simulations of adsorption and desorption of BTX on a graphite surface and in slit and cylindrical pores with different pore sizes at 298 K to investigate the adsorption affinity at zero loading and the adsorption capacity at high loadings. It was found that the side chains (methyl group) on the aromatics ring increase the affinity in the order benzene < toluene < xylene but decrease the capacity at high loadings (benzene > toluene > xylene).

Adsorption Equilibria of Aromatic Compounds on Activated Carbon, Silica Gel, and 13X Zeolite
Wang, Ching-Mei; Chang, Kuei-Sen; Chung, Tsair-Wang; Wu, Honda
Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data

The adsorption of volatile org. compds. (VOCs) on the activated carbon, silica gel, and type-13X synthetic zeolite were investigated by a gravimetric adsorption method.  The sorbates (VOCs) include benzene, toluene, o-xylene, p-xylene, and m-xylene.  The equil. isotherm data obtained from this study were fitted by the Freundlich equation.  The std. deviations for the predicted adsorption isotherms in the activated carbon bed were from 0.44 to 0.92, and the std. deviations were from 0.25 to 4.79 in the silica gel bed and were from 0.12 to 0.87 in the zeolite 13X bed.
Equilibrium Isotherms of the Adsorption of Pyrolysis Gases from Polymer Products
Equilibrium Isotherms of the Adsorption of Pyrolysis Gases from Polymer Products
Lai, Ming-Hong; Shih, Yi-Ling; Chen, Yi-Hua; Shu, Shih-Hong; Chung, Tsair-Wang

There are many polymer products used in homes, and there is great concern about the toxic compds. which may be produced from these in the case of fire.  Typical polymer-based products used in homes - poly(ethylene terephthalate), Nylon6, Nylon66, polystyrene, polypropene, and polyethylene products - were selected to identify pyrolysis gases for adsorption equil. study.  Pyrolysis gases from heating the samples of polymer-based products were analyzed by TGA/automatic thermal desorption/gas chromatog./mass spectrometry.  From the adsorption equil. data, activated C was more efficient than silica gel and zeolite 13X in the adsorption of the pyrolysis gases.  Adsorption uptakes of the pyrolysis gases of arom., alkane, alkene, alc., ketone, epoxide, and acid gases on activated C are in the range of (10 to 50) ppm, and the adsorption uptake of acid gases was the highest.  The regression model for the equil. isotherm data using the Freundlich equation was also developed.

Abs. adsorption isotherms for N at -195° and C6H6 and n-hexane at 20° were measured on a series of graphitized thermal C blacks.  Differential heats of adsorption were also measured as a function of surface coverage.  For N, the initial portion of the isotherm is slightly convex and can be described in terms of localized adsorption, taking into account interaction of adsorbate mols.  For C6H6, the initial portion is concave, with the heat of adsorption being practically const. over the entire monolayer range.  For n-hexane, the initial portion is convex and the heat of adsorption rises by about 15% during monolayer coverage.  The heats of adsorption are in good agreement with previously calcd. values of the potential energy of adsorption.

Computer-Simulations of Benzene Adsorbed on Graphite. 1. 85 K
Computer simulations of benzene adsorbed on graphite.  1.  85 K

Computer simulations of the structure and energy of C6H6 layers adsorbed on graphite at 85 K are presented.  Models for the C6H6-C6H6 and the C6H6-solid interaction potentials are developed.  These give a stable √7 × √7 commensurate film, in agreement with expt.  It is shown that the orientations of these adsorbed mols. are not entirely parallel to the surface as generally assumed.  The fraction of nonparallel mols. in the monolayer is small but increases with increasing coverage.  The bilayer film was also studied; this film has somewhat less stabilization energy than the bulk crystal, but does not transform into the bulk during the duration of the simulation.  Also, the second layer is orientationally less well ordered than the first.  Comparisons with available exptl. data are made.
Computer-Simulations of Benzene Adsorbed on Graphite. 2. 298 K
Computer simulations of benzene adsorbed on graphite.  2.  298 K

Computer simulations of the structures and energies of C6H6 films on graphite at 298 K are reported.  The nearly const. heat of adsorption obsd. in the submonolayer coverage region is the result of a cancellation of an increasing (neg.) av. benzene-benzene interaction energy by the decreasing (neg.) av. benzene-graphite energy.  It is shown that the decrease in the benzene-graphite interaction on this homogeneous surface is a consequence of the changing orientation of the adsorbate mols. relative to the surface.  As coverage increases, a larger fraction of mols. are oriented with their planes nearly perpendicular to the surface.  Since the mol. models used give a weaker benzene-solid interaction for surface-perpendicular than for surface-parallel orientations, the av. mol.-solid interaction decreases with increasing coverage.  Simulations at coverages ≤2 layers are reported.  The role of mol. orientation in detg. the energies and densities of bilayer films is briefly discussed.

In a previous paper, the authors studied the melting transition of C6H6 on the basal plane of graphite at monolayer coverage by using mol. dynamics simulations.  Here, the authors extend this study to include the effects of increasing the coverage to multiple layers.  The authors consider the temp. dependence of certain static and dynamic quantities across a wide temp. range in terms of the published exptl. phase behavior and also compare these results to those of the adsorbed monolayer.
Adsorption of Benzene on Graphitized Thermal Carbon Black: Reduction of the Quadrupole Moment in the Adsorbed Phase
Adsorption of Benzene on Graphitized Thermal Carbon Black: Reduction of the Quadrupole Moment in the Adsorbed Phase
Do, D. D.; Do, H. D.

The performance of intermol. potential models on the adsorption of benzene on graphitized thermal carbon black at various temps. was studied.  Two models contain only dispersive sites, whereas the other two models account explicitly for the dispersive and electrostatic sites.  Using numerous data in the literature on benzene adsorption on graphitized thermal carbon black at various temps., the effect of surface mediation on interaction between adsorbed benzene mols. must be accounted for to describe correctly the adsorption isotherm as well as the isosteric heat.  Among the two models with partial charges tested, the WSKS model of Wick et al. that has only six dispersive sites and three discrete partial charges is better than the very expensive all-atom model of Jorgensen and Severance.  Adsorbed benzene mols. on graphitized thermal carbon black have a complex orientation with respect to distance from the surface and also with respect to loading.  At low loadings, they adopt the parallel configuration relative to the graphene surface, whereas at higher loadings (still less than monolayer coverage) some mols. adopt a slant orientation to maximize the fluid-fluid interaction.  For loadings in the multilayer region, the orientation of mols. in the 1st layer is influenced by the presence of mols. in the 2nd layer.  The data that were used come from the work of Isirikyan and Kiselev, Pierotti and Smallwood, Pierce and Ewing, Belyakova, Kiselev, and Kovaleva, and Carrott et al.
Equilibria and Dynamics for Mixed Vapors of BTX in an Activated Carbon Bed
Equilibria and dynamics for mixed vapors of BTX in an activated carbon bed
Yun, Jeong-Ho; Choi, Dae-Ki; Kim, Sung-Hyun

Exptl. and theor. studies were made on the adsorption of benzene, toluene, p-xylene, and their binary and ternary mixts. by activated carbon in an isothermal condition of 303 K.  Exptl. isotherms for pure components were measured by two kinds of exptl. techniques: the static volumetric method and breakthrough data anal.  Breakthrough data anal. shows that both the extended Langmuir equation and the ideal adsorbed soln. theory could explain mixt. isotherm data with good accuracy.  In addn., a math. model was developed to simulate the column dynamics of pure and mixed vapor adsorption systems.  To represent the mass transfer rate inside the adsorbent particle, the linear driving force approxn. model was applied.  By optimizing the pure and the binary component breakthrough curve data with a dynamic model, an empirical correlation was proposed to represent the overall mass transfer rates for the BTX vapor activated carbon system.  Results with this correlation, which is a function of the partial pressures for each adsorbate and interstitial bulk fluid velocities, showed that the prediction agrees well with the exptl. data of ternary breakthrough curves.
Comparative Adsorption of Simple Molecules on Carbon Nanotubes: Dependence of the Adsorption Properties on the Nanotube Morphology
Comparative adsorption of simple molecules on carbon nanotubes Dependence of the adsorption properties on the nanotube morphology
Masenelli-Varlot, K.; McRae, E.; Dupont-Pavlovsky, N.

Adsorption isotherms of krypton between 77.5 and 83.7 K and ethylene between 90 and 100.5 K on carbon multi-walled nanotubes were measured.  The comparison of the results with those obtained under the same conditions on graphite are discussed in the light of the nanotube morphol.  The curvature of the graphene sheets constituting the nanotube walls mainly results in higher condensation pressures and a lower heat of adsorption with respect to those on a planar surface.  Near the completion of the krypton first condensed layer, a transition to a phase of higher d. occurs, the nature of which is discussed.  The wetting transition temp. above which a second ethylene monomol. layer can condense on the surface is higher on nanotubes than on graphite.

Terzyk, Artur P.; Gauden, Piotr A.; Furmaniak, Sylwester; Wesolowski, Radoslaw P.; Harris, Peter J. F.; Kowalczyk, Piotr

Freezing and Melting of Kr in Hexagonally Shaped Pores of Turbostratic Carbon: Lack of Hysteresis between Freezing and Melting
Freezing and melting of Kr in hexagonally shaped pores of turbostratic carbon. Lack of hysteresis between freezing and melting

To examine the effect of pore-wall structure on freezing and melting behavior of a confined material in mesopores, we measured x-ray diffraction patterns from Kr confined in 2 kinds of ordered mesoporous carbons with hexagonally shaped pores, compared with ordered mesoporous SiO2 with cylindrical pores, during freezing and melting processes.  The ordered mesoporous C possesses cryst. C walls with turbostratic stacking structure, whereas the pore walls of the mesoporous SiO2 are amorphous.  Large depressions in m. p. of the confined Kr were obsd. for both the ordered mesoporous C and SiO2.  For the Kr confined in the amorphous pores of the mesoporous SiO2, thermal cycling showed pronounced hysteresis between freezing and melting, in agreement with previous results.  On the other hand, for the Kr confined in the cryst. pores of the mesoporous C, freezing and melting took place almost reversibly.
Layer-by-Layer Freezing of Kr Confined in Hexagonal Pores with Crystalline Carbon Walls
Layer-by-Layer Freezing of Kr Confined in Hexagonal Pores with Crystalline Carbon Walls

To examine the origin of the lack of hysteresis between freezing and melting for Kr confined in the hexagonal pores with cryst. carbon walls, the authors measured x-ray diffraction patterns from Kr adsorbed in the ordered mesoporous carbon as a function of pore filling at three temps. in the vicinity of the f.p. of a confined phase.  The structure of the 1st layer adjacent to the pore walls formed at a temp. below the f.p. is compatible with the 3-dimensional structure of the confined bulk crystal.  The 1st bilayer adjacent to the cryst. walls of the mesoporous carbon still keeps its crystallinity at a temp. 6 K higher than the f.p.  Therefore, for a liq. Kr confined in the cryst. carbon pores, the cryst. bilayer film that is commensurate with the bulk structure of the confined solid Kr is already in place at a boundary between the liq. and the carbon pore walls at the equil. f.p. and thus plays a role as a crit. nucleus in freezing of the interior phase.
Characterization of a New Solid Having Graphitic Hexagonal Pores with a GCMC Technique
Characterization of a New Solid Having Graphitic Hexagonal Pores with a GCMC Technique
Wang, Yao; Nguyen, Phuong T. M.; Sakao, Noriyuki; Horikawa, Toshihide; Do, D. D.; Morishige, Kunimitsu; Nicholson, D.

Recently, Morishige synthesized a new and exciting porous carbon material that has regular and nonconnected hexagonal pores with graphitic walls.  Classical theories, such as the BJH or the DFT method, are unsuitable to characterize this material because the kernel (family of local isotherms) is based on model cylindrical pores.  The authors present a new characterization based on a GCMC simulation of hexagonal pores that can account for the pore size, the surface morphol., and the heterogeneity arising from either structural or energetic defects.  The mol. model describes the adsorption isotherms and the isosteric heat at 77.4 and 87.3 K over a wide range of pressures.  This new material and the successful mol. model provide one with an ideal system to study adsorption mechanisms in a confined space, including the effects of confinement on the 2-dimensional transition for temps. below the triple point and the 3-dimensional-capillary condensation for temps. below the crit. point of the bulk fluid.

Adsorption of Aromatic Compounds onto Activated Carbons: Effects of the Orientation of the Adsorbates
Adsorption of Aromatic Compounds onto Activated Carbons: Effects of the Orientation of the Adsorbates
Haghseresht, F.; Finnerty, J. J.; Nouri, S.; Lu, G. Q.

Adsorption of model arom. compds. onto 2 untreated activated carbons with similar phys. and chem. properties is studied.  The soln. pH of all expts. was lowered so that all solutes were in their mol. forms.  The difference in the max. adsorption capacities of the solutes was mainly attributed to the difference in the sizes of the mols.  This new exptl. finding is significant to gaining insight into the orientation of the adsorbed phase and hence the adsorption mechanism of arom. compds. in aq. solns.  The adsorption of arom. compds. in a stacked motif for π-π interactions is unlikely, and in the absence of phys. restrictions such as pore width, a T-shaped motif is the preferred orientation.
Multilayer Adsorption of Benzene on Graphitised Thermal Carbon Black: The Importance of Quadrupole and Explicit Hydrogen in the Potential Model
Multilayer adsorption of benzene on graphitised thermal carbon black. The importance of quadrupole and explicit hydrogen in the potential model
Klomkliang, Nikom; Do, D. D.; Nicholson, D.; Tangsathitkulchai, C.; Wongkoblap, A.

Grand Canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation was used to study multilayer adsorption of benzene on graphitized thermal carbon black over a range of temp. between 273 K and 373 K.  3 Potential models for benzene were compared: TraPPE-UA-9, OPLS-AA and TraPPE-EH, to study their capability to correctly describe the adsorption isotherms and isosteric heats.  In the sub-monolayer region, there is no difference between the simulation results obtained with the three models, which all describe the exptl. data well.  However, in the multilayer region only the TraPPE-EH model, that includes the quadrupole moment and explicit modeling of the hydrogen, is able to describe the exptl. data accurately; the other 2 models significantly under-predict the data.  The TraPPE-EH model was then used to investigate the microscopic behavior of the adsorbed phase: the local d. distribution and the orientation of various layers, particularly the change in orientation of benzene in the first layer with increase in loading from sub-monolayer to multilayer.  The orientation of benzene mols. in the first layer is affected by the presence of mols. in the higher layers, but that most benzene mols. remain in an orientation parallel to the surface, which is favored by the interaction with the surface, while a smaller population takes 60° and vertical orientations to the surface which maximizes the entropy.  The ratio of the no. of mols. having parallel orientation to that having 60° and vertical orientations decreases in higher layers due to the weaker influence of the adsorbate-adsorbent interaction.  Detailed study of the orientation shows that most slant and vertical mols. have 2 of their H atoms closer to the surface.
Temperature Effects on the Retention of n-Alkanes and Arenes in Helium-Squalane Gas-Liquid Chromatography: Experiment and Molecular Simulation
Temperature effects on the retention of n-alkanes and arenes in helium-squalane gas-liquid chromatograph. Experiment and molecular simulation
Wick, Collin D.; Siepmann, J. Ilja; Klotz, Wendy L.; Schure, Mark R.

Expts. and mol. simulations were carried out to study temp. effects (at 323-383 K) on the abs. and relative retention of n-hexane, n-heptane, n-octane, benzene, toluene and the three xylene isomers in gas-liq. chromatog.  Helium and squalane were used as the carrier gas and retentive phase, resp.  Both the expts. and the simulations show a markedly different temp. dependence of the retention for the n-alkanes compared to the arenes.  For example, over the 60 K temp. range studied, the Kovats retention index of benzene increases by ∼16 or 18 ± 10 retention index units detd. from the expts. or simulations, resp.  For toluene and the xylenes, the exptl. measured increases are similar in magnitude and range from 14 to 17 retention index units for m-xylene to o-xylene.  The mol. simulation data provide an independent method of obtaining the transfer enthalpies and entropies.  The change in retention indexes is the result of the larger entropic penalty and the larger heat capacity for the transfer of the alkane mols.
Monte Carlo Simulations of the Hydration of Substituted Benzenes with OPLS Potential Functions
Monte Carlo simulations of the hydration of substituted benzenes with OPLS potential functions
Jorgensen, William L.; Nguyen Toan, B.

Intermol. potential functions have been developed for use in computer simulations of substituted benzenes.  Previously reported optimized potentials for liq. simulations (OPLS) for benzene and org. functional groups were merged and tested by computing free energies of hydration for toluene, p-xylene, phenol, anisole, benzonitrile, p-cresol, hydroquinone, and p-dicyanobenzene.  The calcns. featured Monte Carlo simulations at 25° and 1 atm with statistical perturbation theory.  The av. difference between the computed results and exptl. data for the abs. free energies of hydration is 0.5 kcal/mol. Physical Interaction of Gases with Crystalline Solids. 1. Gas-Solid Energies and Properties of Isolated Adsorbed Atoms
Physical interaction of gases with crystalline solids.  I.  Gas-solid energies and properties of isolated adsorbed atoms

The potential energy of a gas atom interacting with a solid having a surface made up of a single type of exposed lattice plane can be expressed as a Fourier series in the position variables in the plane parallel to the surface.  Assuming that the total interaction is a pair-wise sum of gas atom-solid atom terms, an analytic expression for the Fourier coeffs. is obtained for inverse power law interactions.  Gas-solid potentials calcd. for several surface lattices by direct summation are compared with those given by the truncated Fourier series, and a satisfactory representation in the energy is obtained even when the no. of terms included is small.  The truncated series is then utilized to calc. the Henry law adsorption consts. and av. energies for an isolated adsorbed atom.  These results are compared with calcns. based on completely localized and perfectly mobile adsorption models.

A New Method to Determine Pore Size and Its Volume Distribution of Porous Solids Having Known Atomistic Configuration
A new method to determine pore size and its volume distribution of porous solids having known atomistic configuration
Do, D. D.; Herrera, L. F.; Do, H. D.
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science

A simple method, based on Monte Carlo integration, is presented to derive pore size and its vol. distribution for porous solids having known configuration of solid atoms.  Because pores do not have any particular shape, it is important that we define the pore size in an unambiguous manner and the vol. assocd. with each pore size.  The void vol. that we adopt is the one that is accessible to the center of mass of the probe particle.  We test this new method with porous solids having well defined pores such as graphitic slit pores and carbon nanotubes, and then apply it to obtain the pore vol. distribution of complex solids such as disordered solids, rectangular pores, defected graphitic pores, metal org. framework and zeolite.

Lillo-Rodenas, M. A.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M.; Cazorla-Amoros, D.; Linares-Solano, A.

Previous studies of the adsorption of benzene and toluene at low concn. showed that both porosity and surface chem. of the activated carbon play an important role.  This paper analyses the adsorption behavior of a mixt. of VOCs (benzene-toluene) on AC, due to the lack of information regarding the adsorption of mixts.  Thus, the performance of chem. activated carbons, phys. activated carbon with steam and com. samples is studied.  This study shows that chem. activated carbons have better performance than the other samples, showing much higher adsorption capacities, breakthrough times and sepn. times.  Porosity is a key factor and those activated carbons with higher vols. of micropores exhibit higher adsorption capacities and breakthrough times.  This work also analyses the state of the adsorbed phase resulting from the mixt. adsorption and comparison of the compn. of the adsorbed hydrocarbons with that predicted by the ideal adsorption soln. theory (IAST), shows good agreement.
